awd_abstract_narration:
A three-dimensional manifold is locally modelled on the space in which we live, but globally it can be quite different.  Such manifolds and their higher-dimensional variants have proved to be astonishingly important, arising in many branches of mathematics and physics. Recently, study of these manifolds has seen a period of remarkable transformation, with progress made by understanding symmetries of the manifolds and the related so-called "covering spaces."  These are succinctly encoded by a purely algebraic object known as the fundamental group. The interplay between the fundamental group and the manifold is at the center of this research project. The project aims to better understand more general groups in addition to those arising from manifolds. Recent work has focused on the longstanding question of how one might recognize various classes of groups from "local data" and on trying to reconstitute the group as global data.

This project is focused on representations, in various settings, of groups arising in low-dimensional geometry and topology (e.g. free groups, surface groups, and Kleinian groups). The project addresses questions of distinguishing such groups in the setting of finitely-generated residually finite groups by their profinite completions. Remarkably, the case of the free group is still open and continues to provide focus for work in this direction. The project also addresses connections with number theory, algebraic geometry, mapping class groups, and the topology of higher dimensional hyperbolic manifolds. Among other objectives is a better understanding of the arithmetic of canonical components of character varieties of knot groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Symmetry is an all-pervasive notion in mathematics, and this can often be captured by the notion of a group.  A major theme in modern (geometric) group theory is to study groups by looking at their actions on different sets or spaces. The most basic case being that a group G acts on a finite set X, and this leads to a collection of finite groups which are images of G. This can sometimes be empty but in many naturally occuring cases this set of finite images is large and interesting. In this case, one can package the finite image groups of G into a larger group called the profinite completion ^G of G.  A group G is profinitely rigid if the set of finite image groups of G completely determines G (modulo some technical fussing that will be ommitted). Equivalently whenever ^H =^G then H=G.  A major open question going back to the 1970's is to establish profinite rigidity when G is a free non-abelian group. The PI has worked on this, and related questions (primarily with M.R. Bridson, Oxford) and in work with Bridson, McReynolds and Spitler provided the first examples of groups that were "like the free group" and profinitely rigid.

The work of the PI and collaborators has been the catalyst for a resurgence in the study of Profinite Rigidity recently, and their will be a workshop on Profinite Rigidity in Madrid in June 2023.

A crucial feature of the groups that were constructed above is the arithmetic structure of these groups, and the PI has long been interested in studying groups that arise from arithmetic constructions,  and over the course of the grant the PI (and collaborators) have constructed many new examples of hyperbolic 4-manifolds with embedded submanifolds, all of which are arithmetic in nature.

As for Broader Impacts of the project: The PI has advised 6 PhD students over the course of the grant (one of whom is a URM female and another is a URM male), with two graduating in May 2022 (one of whom will take up a NSF funded RTG instructorship at UT Austin, and the a PIMS Postdoc at UBC). All of these students are working on problems closely related to the themes of the grant, and mutiple publications by some of these PhD students have arisen over the course of the grant. The PI has now graduated 19 PhD students (including 4 female), most of whom remain in academia. In addition the PI has mentored two postdocs over the course of the grant (one of whom, Ryan Spitler, is a NSF Postdoc).

The PI co-organized a workshop "Arithmetic Groups and 3-Manifolds" at Max Planck Institut Bonn in May 2022, the first workshop to be held in person at Max Planck since the pandemic began. Many of the themes of the grant were covered in lectures delivered at the workshop.

Although not directly related to the grant, the PI would like to note that over the course of the grant, he was Chair of the Department of Mathematics at Rice University, where he demonstrated his commitment to DEI issues in many aspects of the department's mission; e.g. in the recruitment of Chelsea Walton.
